Introduction:
Hello, my name is Léonie! Thank you for your interest in Glendon, a faculty and campus of York University! I am happy to answer your questions!
How much is tuition, fees, cost?

For details about tuition fees for Canadian and international students, please visit this link: https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/future-students/tuition-and-fees/. Scroll down to find the fees for international students. Note that the fees differ between domestic and international students.

Also, fees depend on the number of courses in which you register and can vary depending on how many credits you are taking, each term. The fees appearing on our website assume a student is taking a full- time course load (30 credits) over the course of the Fall (September to December) and Winter (January to April) terms (i.e., 15 credits per term). You will see on this same page price ranges for residence and meal plans, as well as the price for the health/dental plan.
What do I do now that I have applied?

If you have already applied for admission to Glendon, you can view your next steps by clicking on the following link: https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/future-students/applied/. Within 5 to 7 days, you should receive an email from York University with your student ID number, instructions on how to log into your account, and information on the next steps. If you do not receive this email, please contact our office at liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
What are the admission requirements?

For more information about admission requirements, click on the following link and choose number #2: https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/apply/ or Admission Requirements | Future Students | York University and follow the steps. If you need assistance, please contact our office at liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
What is the deadline to apply?

To view the application deadlines for admission based on applicant type, click on this link: https://www.glendon.yorku.ca/futurestudents/apply/dates-and-deadlines/. If you need assistance, please contact our office at liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
I have more questions, what is your contact information?
For more information, you can send an email to liaison@glendon.yorku.ca or visit our website: A smart choice for future students | Glendon Campus | York University
I am a mature student, where can I find more information?

For mature students, please find all the information on this webpage; https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/future-students/mature-and-transfer-students/. If you have more questions, you can find on our website a full list of our programs: https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/programs/search-our-programs/. I would encourage you to take a look at our admission requirements, selecting the option that best aligns with your educational background. When you are ready to apply, you can do so through directly on York’s website. The application deadlines can be seen on our website, based on applicant type. Everything is done online, for more information on how to apply, please click on the following link: https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/apply/. If you have any other questions on how to apply or our programs, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca
How can I apply for a room in residence at Glendon?
To reserve a room in our residence visit: https://www.yorku.ca/housing/glendon/.

Glendon applicants can apply to stay in one of our two on-campus residences, Hilliard or Wood. More information can be found online here and here. Meal plans are mandatory for all Glendon students living in residence – you can read more about the meal plan options here. If this is your first year, all students who apply before the deadline, typically by the end of May, are guaranteed a room in our residence. After that, it depends on availability. 90% of our rooms are singles. For more information about residences, you can contact Housing Services at residence@glendon.yorku.ca or 416-487-6844.
I am an international student; how can I pay the fees?

You can find payment information for international students here: https://sfs.yorku.ca/fees/your- student-account/paying and we suggest using CIBC for international student. Visit this link if you are ready to pay some fees: https://sfs.yorku.ca/fees/paying/convera
I am an international student; how can I pay the deposit?

You can find payment information for international students here: https://sfs.yorku.ca/fees/your- student-account/paying and we suggest using CIBC for international student. Visit this link if you are ready to pay some fees: https://sfs.yorku.ca/fees/paying/convera
I would like to pursue a master's program?

Glendon has a select few master's and doctorate programs, which you can access here; Graduate Programs at Glendon | Glendon Campus (yorku.ca) and for questions regarding master or doctorate studies; you may visit https://www.yorku.ca/gradstudies/ or contact them at: fgsapply@yorku.ca.

If you are interested in one of the graduate-level programs offered at Glendon, you will need to reach out to the appropriate graduate program office directly to speak with someone about admission requirements. Here are the relevant departmental contact details:
Master's in Public and International Affairs (MPIA) – publicaffairs@glendon.yorku.ca
Masters of Conference Interpreting (MCI) – interpretation@glendon.yorku.ca
Masters of French Studies (MA) & Doctorate in Études francophones (PhD) – frengraduate@glendon.yorku.ca
Masters of Translation (MA) – matrans@glendon.yorku.ca

You may wish to also look at the various graduate programs available at York’s Keele campus. For information about any of these programs, you can reach out to the Recruitment Team for the Faculty of Graduate Studies at fgsnews@yorku.ca.

When is the open house at Glendon?

If you are interested in visiting our campus, we have a few options for you. Visit Glendon Student Recruitment Eventbrite page, to find out about our open house and other activities, and to reserve your spot. We look forward to welcoming you to our campus.
Where can I register for the open house at Glendon?
You can visit Glendon Student Recruitment Eventbrite page to find out about our open house and other activities, and to reserve your spot. We look forward to welcoming you to our campus.
I would like to visit the Glendon campus, how can I book a visit?

If you are interested in doing a campus tour, we have a few options for you. Visit Glendon Student Recruitment Eventbrite page, to find out about our open house and other activities, and to reserve your spot. We look forward to welcoming you to our campus.
GENERAL ADMISSIONS & APPLICATION QUESTIONS
I would like to know more about Glendon?

You can find on our website a full list of our programs: https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/programs/search-our-programs/. I would encourage you to take a look at our admission requirements, selecting the option that best aligns with your educational background.

When you are ready to apply, you can do so through the Ontario Universities Application Centre (OUAC), or directly on York’s website. The application deadlines can be seen on our website, based on applicant type. Everything is done online, for more information on how to apply, please click on the following link: https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/apply/. I am an Ontario high school student; can you give me more information?

If you are an Ontario high school student; I would encourage you to look on our website at the list of undergraduate programs available at Glendon. You can see the admission requirements for Ontario high school students on our website as well. In the evaluation of your application, Admissions will require six 4U/4M courses, including English 4U, if you attend an English language high school or French 4U if you attend a French language high school. Some programs also have 4U/4M prerequisites, which are listed directly under the general requirements. Your average is calculated based on the top six M/U courses, including the prerequisites. If you intend to apply to a program with prerequisites, it will be important that you have taken or be actively taking these courses at the time of application. If you have any other questions, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
I am an Ontario high school student, what are the admission requirements for Glendon programs?

If you are an Ontario high school student; I would encourage you to look on our website at the list of undergraduate programs available at Glendon. You can see the admission requirements for Ontario high school students on our website as well. In the evaluation of your application, Admissions will require six 4U/4M courses, including English 4U, if you attend an English language high school or French 4U if you attend a French language high school. If you have any other questions, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.

How do I submit an application?

If you are a high school student, when you are ready to apply, you can do so through the Ontario Universities Application Centre (OUAC). If you are international student, a mature or transfer student: you can apply through the Ontario Universities Application Centre (OUAC) or directly on York’s website. The application deadlines based on applicant type can be seen on our website. I encourage you to look at the requirements: Admission Requirements | Future Students | York University. Everything is done online, for more information on how to apply, please click on the following link: https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/apply/
I am doing IB, what are the requirements?

If you are an IB Student, I would encourage you to take look at our website, for a list of programs; https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/programs/search-our-programs/. As a student of an IB program, you can see the specific admission requirements for our programs on our website. Our general requirement for admission consideration is the successful completion of the IB diploma with passes in 6 subjects – either 3 Standard Level (SL) passes, and 3 Higher Level (HL) passes, or 2 Standard Level (SL) passes and 4 Higher Level (HL) passes. Note that some programs also have specific requirements that you must meet – these are listed directly under the General Requirements. Also, you can receive up to 30 transfer credits.

French Baccalaureate or International Baccalaureate student?

As a French Bac (baccalauréat français) student or if you are an international student, you can apply through the Ontario Universities Application Centre (OUAC) or directly on the York University website. You can view the application deadlines on our website. I encourage you to look at the requirements: Admission Requirements | Future Students | York University. If you have any other questions, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
I am considered a mature student?

By definition, a mature student will be at least 20 years old by the end of the year in which they are admitted to the University, have been out of high school for at least two years (or have returned to upgrade after a two year absence), have attempted less than a year at college/university, have a favourable academic record and have demonstrated potential for success at the university level (through academic, work, volunteer activities, etc.). You can find the admission requirements for a mature student here and the steps on how to apply here and if you are ready, apply here:Apply Now For
Glendon University Programs | Glendon Campus (yorku.ca). If you have any other questions, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
I would like to transfer to Glendon from a college or university, where can I find the information?

If you are pursuing a college degree or University degree or have completed post-secondary-level studies, your application would follow the requirements of a transfer student. You can read more about the application process itself here. You can submit your application through the Ontario Universities Application Centre (OUAC), or directly on York’s website. The application deadlines can be viewed on our website, based on applicant type. If you have any other questions, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
Can I have some credits for courses done at a college or a university?

If you have completed some post-secondary-level studies, your application would follow the requirements of a transfer student. In reviewing your file, admissions will automatically consider you for transfer credits from your previous studies. The exact number of transfer credits for which you may be eligible cannot be determined in advance as the Office of Admissions will consider many factors in the evaluation of your file. Should you receive an offer letter, it will include a pre-assessment of the number of transfer credits you may be eligible to receive; this number can be confirmed during your initial enrolment appointment by your academic advisor. If you have any other questions, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
What are the admission requirements for college transfer?

The general admission requirement for a college transfer applicant is to have completed either a college diploma or at least 2 full semesters or one year of full-time studies at an accredited college. You must have achieved a minimum overall average of 3.0 on a 4-point scale (70% or B or equivalent). University transfer applicants must have completed at least 4 full courses or 1 year of full-time academic studies and received a minimum average of 2.0 on a 4-point scale (60% or C or equivalent) for a 3-year program or 2.3 on a 4-point scale (65% or C+ or equivalent) for a 4-year (Honours program). Some programs also have program-specific prerequisites – these are listed under the general requirements; https://futurestudents.yorku.ca/requirements. If you have a GPA below cutoff, we encourage you to contact our office, each situation is different, and we might be able to advise on the best steps or options for you. If you have more specific questions, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
May I have more information about the TRANSLATION Program and the ACCELERATED TRANSLATION PROGRAM?

Our Professional Translation program allows students to specialize in English to French translation, or French to English translation, based on their dominant language. The program is also offered as an Accelerated BA [60 credits] for existing university degree holders. You do not need to have a degree in a related field to apply to the Accelerated program. You can read more about the program requirements

on our website here for the BA in Professional Translation, and here for the Accelerated BA. You can also take a look at the program’s detailed map in order to gain a better understanding of what your journey through this program could look like, and ways through which you can enhance your degree. You will need to successfully complete the School of Translation’s qualifying exam as part of the application process for both the BA and Accelerated BA. To write the exam, please contact the School of Translation directly at translation@glendon.yorku.ca. I would recommend that you do this before applying as it is the least expensive part of the process. Once you pass the exam, you can formally submit your application. If you have any other questions, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
Could I receive more information about the Master’s IN TRANSLATION?
For more information about the Master’s in Translation, please contact matrans@glendon.yorku.ca.
How do I submit the supplementary application for the dual degree?

Dual Degree applicants must follow the instructions on this page: Supplementary Application | International Studies & Business Administration Dual Degree (yorku.ca) to submit their supplementary application . Once received, we will forward it directly to the evaluation committee for their evaluation. Please note that the supplementary application includes four (4) questions, two (2) in English and two (2) in French, that you will need to answer in both written/video format. If you have already applied to the Dual Degree at Glendon and require more information about submitting your supplementary application, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
What is the deadline to submit the supplementary application for the Dual Degree?

Offers to the Dual Degree will formally begin to go out on a rolling basis starting in early in the first months of the new year (typically around February). We recommend that you submit your Supplementary Application as soon as possible by the end of March. Spaces in the Dual Degree are limited, so getting your supplementary application in early will help ensure you are considered for the program. If you have already applied to the Dual Degree at Glendon and require more information, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
Do I need to speak French to apply to the Dual Degree?

The Dual Degree in International Studies and Business Administration offered in partnership with emlyon business school in France does indeed require that applicants already have good knowledge of both French and English to apply. This program is highly prescribed in nature and has students studying in both languages from the onset of their studies. Students are therefore required to submit a supplementary application to showcase their written and verbal capacity in English and French as part of the admissions process, to ensure they have the required language level to succeed in the program. If you have already applied to the Dual Degree at Glendon and require more information about your application, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
Can I apply for a certificate only?
If you already have a university degree (of at least 3 years), you may apply for the following certificates as a standalone (i.e. without simultaneously applying to an undergraduate program at York):
Certificate in Creative Writing Across Contexts
Certificate in Refugee and Migration Studies
Certificate in Spanish for Business and Professional Communication
Certificate in Spanish-English/English-Spanish Translation
Certificate in the Discipline of Teaching English as an International Language (D-TEIL)
Certificate in Technical and Professional Communication
Certificate in Sexuality Studies

Applications for certificate programs must be submitted directly to the York website. As a degree holder, your application will follow the guidelines for a transfer student from a university. Application deadlines are available on our website, depending on the type of applicant.

If you are an international student and you intend on completing a certificate on your own, we strongly recommend that you contact an immigration advisor () to discuss the potential ramifications this could have on study permit/visa approval. It is not possible to study full-time in a certificate unless it is paired with an undergraduate program.
For more information about our certificates, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
How can I take only one or two courses?

If you are looking to take a few courses at Glendon on a non-degree basis, your application will follow that of a Visiting Student and should be submitted directly through York University’s online application form. Please note that course registration approval for Visiting Students is at the sole discretion of both the Department and the professor offering the course.
I missed the deadline to submit my application, is it too late?

When the deadline to submit an application for admission for the fall term is passed, applications for our non-competitive programs can still be open. We encourage you to submit your application as soon as possible. I would encourage you to take a look at our admission requirements, selecting the option that best aligns with your educational background. When you are ready to apply, you can do so through the Ontario Universities Application Centre (OUAC), or directly on York’s website. The application deadlines can be seen on our website, based on applicant type. Everything is done online, for more information on how to apply, please click on the following link: https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/apply/. If you have any other questions on how to apply or our programs, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca
I applied but did not receive my reference number from York?
Please note that it can take up to 5 business days for OUAC and Admissions to process your application.

If you have not received a York reference number by the end of the week following your application, please send an email to liaison@glendon.yorku.ca with your full name and date of birth so that we can follow up with the Office of Admissions on your behalf. Be sure to also check your Junk/Spam folders.

If you applied through York University website, within 3 to 5 business days of submitting your application, you will receive your 9-digit York reference number, which will give you access to your MyFile portal, where you can manage your application and upload any documents being requested by the Office of Admissions (under the “Supporting Documents” tab). If you have not received a reference number by the end of the week following your application, please send an email to liaison@glendon.yorku.ca with your full name and date of birth so that we can follow up with the Office of Admissions on your behalf.
I need to take a few more courses to finish my diploma, what do I need to do?

In order to be able to do more courses to finish your program after you stop for a year or longer, you will need to submit a new application. You can reapply either through the Ontario Universities Application Centre (OUAC) or directly on York’s website. If you only plan on reapplying to York University, we recommend applying directly through our website, where you will be able to apply to 2 YorkU programs of your choice. Glendon programs end with “–Glendon". For more information on how to reapply, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
My average (GPA) is too low to be accepted, what should I do?

Applicants who are looking to upgrade their high school marks or to complete any missing high school credits in fulfilment of any program-specific prerequisites can consider taking courses through a virtual, independent, or adult learning centre. We recommend you consider taking these credits through an accredited institution like TVO ILC or, if you are over the age of 19, looking into the adult learning opportunities available through the Government of Ontario.
I am missing a few requirements to be accepted what should I do?

Applicants who are looking to upgrade their high school marks or to complete any missing high school credits in fulfilment of any program-specific prerequisites can consider taking courses through a virtual, independent, or adult learning centre. We recommend you consider taking these credits through an accredited institution like TVO ILC or, if you are over the age of 19, looking into the adult learning opportunities available through the Government of Ontario.
Can I take courses as an auditing student?

Applications to audit courses go through Glendon’s Academic Services (acadservices@glendon.yorku.ca). Auditing students are required to obtain permission from the Department or professor offering the course. There is a $10 fee per credit to audit a class – so $30 for a
3.0-credit course and $60 for a 6.0-credit course. If you have any further questions about auditing, please contact dearadvisor@glendon.yorku.ca
Do I need to submit a proof of language?

You can read more about our language requirements on our website. Please note that these language requirements are not program-specific but, rather, are part of the overall admissions process to the university. The Office of Admissions will need to see your transcripts from your previous studies in order to determine if you already meet the language proficiency requirements. If the Office of Admissions deems you do not meet the requirements, you will then need to provide satisfactory results to one of the language tests accepted by the University. For international students, you must submit transcripts showing four years of study at a French or English institution (such as Lycée, IB, International high school, etc.) or provide a language test score. York's Office of Admissions accepts the Duolingo English Language Placement test.
I am not able to start in September, what can I do?

You can ask for a deferral. You can find more information on next steps for submitting a deferral request here. Students are able to request a deferral for up to one calendar year. Kindly note that deferrals are approved at the discretion of the University, and only one deferral request per offer of admission will be allowed.

Please note that deferrals will only be granted to students who have been accepted to a program, have officially accepted their offer of admission, and have met the conditions outlined in their offer, including but not limited to the submission of all final official documents and transcripts, which need to be provided directly by their previous institution(s). Students requesting a deferral are also not permitted to complete studies in another post-secondary institution between the time they request the deferral and the time they intend to begin their studies at York.
How can I request a deferral?

You can find more information on next steps for submitting a deferral request here. Students are able to request a deferral for up to one calendar year. Kindly note that deferrals are approved at the discretion of the University, and only one deferral request per offer of admission will be allowed. You need to complete the form and then submit.

Please note that deferrals will only be granted to students who have been accepted to a program, have officially accepted their offer of admission and have met the conditions outlined in their offer, including but not limited to the submission of all final official documents and transcripts, which need to be provided directly by their previous institution(s). Students requesting a deferral also are not permitted to complete studies in another post-secondary institution between the time they request the deferral and the time to intend to begin their studies at York.
I would like to switch from one Glendon program to a different Glendon program?

If you have already submitted an application to a Glendon program and would now like to be considered for admission to a different Glendon program, you can make these changes yourself through your OUAC account. You can drop the Glendon program that you want to change, then add an alternate Glendon program of your choice.
If you submitted your application directly through York’s application and would like to change one of the programs, please contact our office at liaison@glendon.yorku.ca
You will have to confirm in writing:
Which of the two applications you would like to change;
The Glendon program to which you would now like to apply.

Note that, if you have already been admitted to this program and choose to drop the application, you will forfeit your offer of admission by dropping the application. Should you need technical support from OUAC, you can reach out to their team. For all other applicants: if you have any further questions, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.

text: I would like to change from one Glendon program to a different Keele campus program or faculty?

If you have applied to a program offered at the Glendon campus but want to be considered for a program offered at the Keele campus, you can make the program change yourself through your OUAC account. You can drop the Glendon application. You can then add the Keele program(s) of your choice. If you submitted your application directly through York’s application and would like to change one of the programs, please contact our office at liaison@glendon.yorku.ca
You will have to confirm in writing:
Which of the two applications you would like to change;
The Glendon or another Faculty program to which you would now like to apply.

Note that, if you had already been admitted to the Glendon program and choose to drop the application, you will forfeit your offer of admission by dropping the application. For further questions regarding your application to any program(s) at the Keele campus, please contact the Office of Admissions directly at study@yorku.ca or 416-736-5000.

What does the “i” stand for in the iBA or iBSC?

The difference between a BA/BSc and an iBA/iBSc, you can read more about this here. The iBA/iBSc folds in a few extra language credits, some additional internationally oriented courses, as well as a mandatory exchange (typically in your 3rd year).
You don’t need to decide now what you prefer doing – you have two options:
You can accept your offer to the BA/BSc and, speak to your academic advisor about switching over to the iBA/iBSc as you get closer to your 3rd year; or

If you would like to be formally considered for the iBA/iBSc right away, you can make this change directly in your OUAC account. What is the difference between the BA and iBA or BSC and iBSC?

The difference between a BA/BSc and an iBA/iBSc, you can read more about this here. The iBA/iBSc folds in a few extra language credits, some additional internationally oriented courses, as well as a mandatory exchange (typically in your 3rd year).
You don’t need to decide now what you prefer doing – you have two options:
You can accept your offer to the BA/BSc and, speak to your academic advisor about switching over to the iBA/iBSc as you get closer to your 3rd year; or

If you would like to be formally considered for the iBA/iBSc right away, you can make this change directly in your OUAC account. If you would like to pursue this option, I would encourage you to contact our office at liaison@glendon.yorku.ca before making the changes so that we can advise you according to your situation and where you are in the process of your application/admission.
I applied, which documents do I have to submit with my application?

When applying, applicants will first be asked to submit their transcripts for all previous studies. From there, depending on your background, the Office of Admissions may also ask you to submit additional documents such as a resume/CV, a letter of intent or, if applicable, a detailed description of any courses you have taken at the post-secondary level, explanations for any previous poor academic performance or proof of language proficiency.

Within 5 business days of submitting your application, you will receive your 9-digit York ID number, which will give you access to your MyFile portal, where you can manage your application and upload any documents being requested by the Office of Admissions (under the “Supporting Documents” tab). We always recommend that students check their MyFile account often (at least once per week) as the list of documents being requested by the Office of Admissions can sometimes change.

While transcripts uploaded to MyFile will not be considered official by York Admissions, they can in many cases, be used for the purpose of making a decision regarding your admission. If you receive an offer of admission to the University, it will be conditional on the receipt of your official transcripts, which must be provided to the Office of Admissions directly by your previous institution(s).

Where can I send my official transcripts?

We accept emailed copies of official transcripts from your previous academic institution(s) as applicable, provided they are sent directly by the institution from a valid institutional email address (not a Hotmail, Gmail, Yahoo, etc.). All documents received from non-institutional email addresses will not be considered official. Transcripts can be emailed to liaison@glendon.yorku.ca and we will forward them to the Office of Admissions on your behalf. mailto:international@glendon.yorku.ca

If your institution(s) would prefer to mail an official hard copy (in a sealed institutional envelope with the institution’s seal or stamp on the back flap of the envelope), this remains an option as well, although it takes longer. Mailed documents can be sent directly to the Office of Admissions at the following address:
York University Office of Admissions
Bennett Centre for Student Services - 3rd Floor Reception 99 Ian Macdonald Blvd
Toronto, ON M3J 1P3 CANADA
I am unable to obtain and submit my official transcripts, what should I do?

When your past institution(s) will not or cannot send us an official copy of your transcript, another option is to go through WES (World Education Services) and request what is called an ICAP (International Credential Advantage Package). Documents validated through WES will also be considered official by the Office of Admissions. If you have more questions about how to proceed with sending your official transcripts, you can contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.
I must submit a detailed course description. What do I need to submit?

To be able to consider you for transfer credits from your previous studies (which could potentially count for the degree you will be pursuing at York), the Office of Admissions is asking you to submit the detailed description of all the courses that you have taken at the post-secondary level. Normally, you can find a detailed description of your courses on the website of your previous institution(s), or it can be obtained from the department under which you studied within the institution(s). You can see an example of a detailed course description on York’s website. Your course descriptions should include as many of the listed elements as possible.
I have been requested to upload additional documents to MyFile, but there are no additional spaces, what should I do?

If you have an additional document to submit with your application but do not see an available upload space in MyFile, you can use the MyDocServe tool to request an additional space. Alternatively, you can send us the documents you would like to add to your file to us here at liaison@glendon.yorku.ca and we can forward them to the Office of Admissions on your behalf.
How can I submit my Proof of Language test?

Uploading language proficiency results to MyFile is not permitted.  You must request an electronic copy of the results be sent directly to YorkU's Office of Admissions by the centre in which you completed the test. Please allow up to 3 weeks for results to be received and processed by the Office of Admissions.
No Description Available
If you wrote the IELTS or the TOEFL, your results can be sent electronically using the York University institution number of 0894. To submit a Canadian Academic English Assessment (CAEL) score,

a Cambridge English Language Assessment (CAE, CPE) score, or a Duolingo score you must log in to your affiliated account and select York University as a recipient institution. To submit a Pearson PTE Academic score, please e-mail your Pearson Score Report Code (SRC) to York University at study@yorku.ca. Please use subject line: “PTE Score Report” and be sure to include your 9-digit York reference number.
I have a document (e.g.: transcript) in a language other than English or French, do you accept them?

York University can accept documents such as transcripts in both English and French. If your document is written in a language other than English or French, it must be accompanied by a translation by a certified translator.
What should I include in a personal statement or a personal letter?

The personal statement or letter you are being asked to submit in conjunction with your application should include your reasons for wanting to attend university and outline your activities (work, travel, family responsibilities, etc.) while you were not enrolled in studies.
I am requested to submit a letter of explanation of marginal academic record, what should I include?

The letter of explanation of marginal academic record (also sometimes called a letter of extenuating circumstances) being requested by the Office of Admissions must explain the reasons for your previous poor academic performance (personal or family reasons, illness, etc.). You will also need to provide compelling arguments as to why you will now prepare to succeed in your studies. It is optional but, if your previous poor academic performance is due to a medical condition, you can include medical documentation in support of your letter.

I have been admitted, what are the next steps?

If you are a Canadian student, your first step will be to accept your offer of admission to Glendon. If you submitted your application through OUAC, you need to accept your offer through OUAC, whereas if you applied directly on York’s website, you must accept your offer through your MyFile account (through the “Application Status” tab).

Once you have officially accepted your offer of admission, your next step will be to book your enrolment appointment. This can be done through your MyFile account (by clicking the “Book/Manage My Enrolment Appointment” tab) or by emailing dearadvisor@glendon.yorku.ca. During your enrolment appointment, your academic advisor will be able to help you ensure you have enrolled in the correct courses and will be able to help answer any questions you have about your program requirements.
Enrolment appointments for the Fall term typically begin in June. If by May, you are still not able to book an appointment, contact Academic Advising at dearadvisor@glendon.yorku.ca.

If you are an international student, there is an additional step required before you can schedule your enrolment appointment. You must pay a deposit to secure your place at our institution. This deposit will enable you to obtain a letter from our institution, which you will need when applying for your study permit.
When do enrolment appointments begin?
Enrolment appointments for the Fall term typically begin in June. If by May, you are still not able to book an appointment, contact Academic Advising at dearadvisor@glendon.yorku.ca.
How can I find my courses in the academic calendar?

Be sure to pay special attention when you search for your program in the Academic Calendar, ensuring you choose the Glendon program! You can then begin looking up the courses you will need to take on the York Courses website. During your enrolment appointment, your academic advisor will be able to help you ensure you have enrolled in the correct courses and will be able to help answer any questions you have about your program requirements. If you run into any difficulties after your appointment or have any specific questions, you can email dearadvisor@glendon.yorku.ca to reach an academic advisor, who will be able to help answer your questions.
How can I book my enrolment appointment?

Only once you have accepted your offer, your next step is to book your enrolment appointment. This can be done through your MyFile account (by clicking the “Book/Manage My Enrolment Appointment” tab). By booking your enrolment appointment early, you will benefit from an earlier appointment on the advisors’ schedule. Enrolment appointments for the Fall typically begin in June and for the Winter, they typically begin in October. If you are not able to book your registration appointment, you can send an email to dearadvisor@glendon.yorku.ca.
How can I enrol in my courses?
Your first step will be to book your enrolment appointment. This can be done through
your MyFile account (by clicking the “Book/Manage My Enrolment Appointment” tab) or by
emailing dearadvisor@glendon.yorku.ca. During your enrolment appointment, your academic advisor
will be able to help you ensure you have enrolled in the correct courses and will be able to

help answer any questions you have about your program requirements. About a week before your scheduled appointment, you can expect to hear from the advisors with next steps for enrolling in your courses. This is also when they open your enrolment window. You will use the York courses website to find your courses. You should also use your program booklet to help guide you throughout the enrolment process. If you need to get in touch with the advisors prior to your appointment, you can reach them at dearadvisor@glendon.yorku.ca.
Do I need to speak French to come to Glendon?

Prior knowledge of French is not a formal admission requirement for most of our programs. However, Glendon degrees require you to take at least one French course in your first year. Additionally, you have the option to take more courses in your program in French. Graduating with a bilingual degree distinguishes our graduates from those of other programs. You can find more information about our language learning pathways on our website. https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/future-students/pathways- and-certifications/
Do I have to take French courses?

Students have the option of taking their courses mostly in English, or in French, or in a combination of both languages. Prior to attending your initial enrolment appointment with a Glendon academic advisor, you will take an online French placement test, which will simply serve to assess your current level of French (no need to study in advance!). The results of your placement test will indicate the level of French as a second language (FSL) course at which you will start. If you are pursuing the Flexible Glendon degree, you would only be required to complete six (6) credits at your placement level, which is the equivalent of two regular courses and usually is taken in your first year. However, to get a Bilingual degree at Glendon, you must fulfill our bilingual requirements by completing a minimum of six credits at the 2000-level in your second language. This isn’t as intimidating as it may seem!

It’s no problem if you don’t have any or very little base knowledge of French – you will simply start at the most beginner level of FSL. You will take the course in which you place in your first year, and then progress upward from there if your degree requires taking 2000-level FSL course that will count towards your degree’s bilingual requirement. If you feel comfortable doing so, you can also take discipline courses in your 2nd language, which can also count toward the bilingual component of your degree.

You can, of course, take more than the minimum requirements in your 2nd language (in fact, we encourage it!) and pursue a Bilingual Certificate (mid-level) or a Certificate in Bilingual Excellence (advanced level). You can also explore Trilingual (English-French-Spanish) options if you wish. This is also something your Academic Advisor can help you understand during your enrolment appointment.
Can I do my courses or my degree online (virtually)?

Most of our programs are offered in person through classroom-based instruction during daytime hours, with the potential in certain cases for a limited selection of courses online or in the evening. The only exception is our program in Accelerated Honours B.A. in Professional Translation for degree holders, which can be done entirely online and some psychologies courses, which gives you some options.
Do you offer CO-OP programs?

While Glendon’s programs do not formally offer a co-op option yet, Glendon students are given many unique opportunities to engage in various experiences this include paid and credited work placements, yes! You can receive credits for the equivalent of one or two courses of your program. These placements are available through various employers and community partners. This allows students to relate theory to a concrete experience within the community, workplace or classroom. As a starting point, I’d encourage you to look at Glendon’s Experiential Education website, which outlines some of the opportunities that are available to students. This is something I would recommend you bring up to your academic advisor as well, especially as you progress in your degree. Your advisor will be able to put you in touch with Experiential Education directly, and you can discuss your options with them.
GLENDON PROGRAM DESCRIPTIONS
I would like more information about the biology program?

Our BSc/iBSc in Biology offers specific focus on the study of conservation biology, ecology, and animal behaviour. You can look at its detailed program map, which will give you a much better idea of what your pathway as a student through this program could look like and ways through which you can enhance your degree. You can also look at the specific degree requirements in York’s Academic Calendar, to get a better feel for the types of courses you could be taking as a Glendon Biology student. If it is medicine that interests you, amazing! You can take biology at Glendon, but you will need to make sure to meet with the academic advisors to insert prerequisite courses into your program to apply to medical school.
I would like more information about the communications program?

Our bilingual Communications program focuses on the relationships between media, culture, language, and technology, with courses organized in three central areas of concentration: 1 – Communication, Culture and Society; 2 – Organizations and Communication; and 3 – Technology and Communication. To gain a better understanding of what your journey through this program could look like and ways through which you can enhance your degree, I would encourage you to look at its detailed program map. You can also look at the specific degree requirements in York’s Academic Calendar, to get a better feel for the types of courses you could be taking as a Glendon Communications student.
I would like more information about the Drama program?
Glendon’s program in Drama & Creative Arts can only be taken as a minor or for the elective courses at the moment.
I would like more information about the Dual Degree program?

The Dual Degree in International Studies and Business Administration is offered in partnership with emlyon business school in France. This program is unique in its design – presently, Glendon does not offer any other dual degrees in partnership with other universities in Canada or internationally.

Graduates of this program receive two degrees – an iBA in International Studies from York University, and a Bachelor of Business Administration (BBA) from emlyon – thus the “dual” nature of the degree. You will spend your first 2 years at Glendon focusing on the International Studies portion of your degree, and your 3rd and 4th years at Emlyon focusing on the Business Administration portion of the degree.

It is important to understand that this program requires that applicants already have good knowledge of both French and English as they will be studying in both languages from the onset of their studies.
During the admission process for this program, you must therefore submit an additional application to demonstrate to the selection committee your ability to speak and write in English and French.
I would like more information about the Economics & Business program?

Our programs in Business Economics allow students to acquire the knowledge needed to better understand business management techniques, and effective and practical business strategies. They offer the choice of three streams of specialization which students can declare in their 3rd or 4th years: Accounting & Finance, Economics & Public Policy, or Mathematical Economics/Economic Theory. Both programs also include courses accredited by the Chartered Professional Accountants (CPA) of Canada. To gain a better understanding of what your journey through these programs may look like, we would encourage you to look at their detailed program map. The Economics program is available as both a 3- year and a 4-year (Honours) program, whereas Business Economics is only available as a 4-year (Honours) program.
I would like more information about the English studies program?

Our program in English Studies focuses on English literary studies. It is as comprehensive and deep-delving as any other leading North American University, covering the history of literature and drama in English in context from its classical roots in ancient Greece and Rome to its present forms as a global phenomenon – but delivered in an ideal environment combining the substantial resources of a large research institution like York University with the intimate small liberal arts college world of small classes and seminars. To gain a better understanding of what the journey of an English Studies major might look like and ways through which you can enhance your degree, you can check out the program’s detailed map. You can also look in York’s Academic Calendar to get a better idea of this program’s specific degree requirements and the types of courses you would see yourself taking as a student in this program.

Do your offer an English as a second language (ESL) program?

While we do offer an undergraduate program in English Studies, it is important to understand that this is not an ESL program (learning English as a second language) – it is a program focusing on English literary studies. To gain a better understanding of what the journey of an English Studies major might look like, you can check out the program’s detailed map.

This having been said, if your first language is French and you are interested in learning English as a second language, you might be interested to learn that you can do so alongside one of Glendon’s undergraduate programs. All our degrees are bilingual in English and French and, within most of our programs (with a few exceptions), students have the option of taking their courses mostly in French or in English, or in a combination of both languages.

Upon admission to Glendon, you will take an online English placement test, which will simply serve to assess your current level of English (no need to study in advance!). The results of your placement test will indicate the level of ESL course at which you will start. You will take the course in which you place in your first year, and then progress upward from there until you can take the 2000-level ESL course that will count towards your bilingual Glendon degree. If you feel comfortable doing so, you can also take discipline courses (i.e., Psychology, International Studies, Political Science, Biology, etc.) in your 2nd language, which can also count toward the bilingual component of your degree.
I need to improve my English before applying to the university, what can I do?

For more information on ELI’s programs, you can contact them directly through their website (using the “Contact Us” button appearing on the right), or by sending an email to yueli@yorku.ca.

This having been said, if your first language is French and you are interested in learning English as a second language, you might be interested to learn that you can do so alongside one of Glendon’s undergraduate programs. All of our degrees are bilingual in English and French and, within most of our programs (with a few exceptions), students have the option of taking their courses mostly in French or in English, or in a combination of both languages.

Upon admission to Glendon, you will take an online English placement test, which will simply serve to assess your current level of English (no need to study in advance!). The results of your placement test will indicate the level of ESL course at which you will start. You will take the course in which you place in your first year, and then progress upward from there until you can take the 2000-level ESL course that will count towards your bilingual Glendon degree. I would like more information about the French Studies program?

Our French Studies program is multi-faceted and gives students the opportunity to study French through the study of language (oral and written competency), literature and linguistics. It is offered as both a 3- year (Ordinary) and 4-year (Honours) degree. I would encourage you to look at the detailed program map, which will give you a better idea of what your journey through this program could look like and ways through which you can enhance your degree.

There are two streams within our French Studies program – a stream for Francophones, and a stream for non-Francophones. If you apply to this program and are granted an offer of admission, when you book your enrolment appointment, like for any of our programs, you will write a placement test in your 2nd language (in your case, French). The results of this test will determine the level at which you will begin your studies within French Studies. Depending on your level of French proficiency, as a French major, you may need to take some pre-major level courses, but these would still count toward your degree as electives. This is something that your Academic Advisor would be able to help you better understand during your enrolment appointment, but I hope this gives you a better idea of how it works.
I would like more information about the Linguistics & Language Studies program?

Our Minor program in Linguistics & Language Studies focuses on the building blocks of languages, on how they change over time, on language acquisition, as well as on the differences between regional accents. As a student in this program, you’ll get the chance to study the different branches of linguistics such as phonetics, morphology, semantics, historical linguistics and sociolinguistics. While our program focuses mainly on English, French and Spanish, it does also examine languages in the broadest sense across the globe. To gain a better understanding of what your journey through the Linguistics & Language Studies could look like and ways through which you can enhance your degree, I would encourage you to look at its detailed program map.

It is worth noting that Linguistics & Language students are also given many unique opportunities to be part of language resources outside the classroom, through opportunities such as research assistantships available through Glendon’s Centre for Research on Language Contact, or work or placement opportunities through our Experiential Education offerings.
I would like more information about the Political Science program?

Political Science is a branch of the social sciences which deals with the study of major issues such as democracy and participation, liberalism and illiberalism, migration and citizenship, peace and conflict, human rights, inequality, corruption and global governance. In order to gain a better understanding of what your journey through the Political Science program could look like and ways through which you can enhance your degree, I would encourage you to look at its detailed program.
I would like more information about the Psychology program?

You can read more about our Psychology program on our website, you can choose a BA or BSc in Psychology. To gain a better understanding of what your journey through this program will look like and ways through which you can enhance your degree, you can also look at its detailed program map. This program examines human behaviour under several different lenses – child development, sensation, perception, animal behaviour, social psychology, abnormal psychology, etc. It also offers a stream in Cognitive Neuropsychology, to which students can declare their intention to pursue in their 3rd year in preparation for their 4th (Honours) year.

Glendon Psychology majors are given many unique opportunities to engage in various kinds of applied experiences during their studies at Glendon – for example, through our on-campus psychology laboratories, the applied research practicum (generally in your 4th year of study) or through part-time employment opportunities. Psychology students can also take part in the Cross-Campus Capstone Classroom (also called C4), through which they can select and work on a project proposed by a partner company with a multidisciplinary group of students. With our small class sizes (the average class size is 26 students), you will be able to get to know your professors on a deeper level and have access to research opportunities that may not be as readily available in a larger institution.
I would like more information about the Sociology program?

Sociology is the study of our social world — of our social lives as individuals, of how people connect as members of various groups, of how societies are organized, and of how they change over time. As a sociology student, you’ll consider the various options facing societies in an increasingly complex, specialized world. As a first step, I would encourage you to take a look at the detailed program map for this program, which will give you a better idea of what your journey through this program could look like and ways through which you can enhance your degree. You can also look at the specific degree requirements for this program in York’s Academic Calendar.
I would like more information about the Exploratory year (Undecided Major program)?

You are not sure which program you want to choose or what field best suits your interest, our Undecided Major is a great option for high school students who are destined for university but aren’t yet quite sure in what discipline they want to study. You would get to take courses in various subject areas during your 1st year to get a taste for the different programs available at Glendon and, in preparation for your 2nd year, you can work with an Academic Advisor to identify a Glendon program (or a combination of Glendon programs) that aligns with your interests and future career aspirations.
I would like more information about THE MASTER OF MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (PMMP)?
The Pathway to the Master of Management Program (or PMMP) is offered in partnership with the Schulich School of Business. Applications to this pathway are open to high-achieving secondary school

students with an overall average of 85%+. Students who are admitted to the PMMP are reserved a spot in the Schulich School of Business’s Master of Management Program (MMgt) upon completion of their Glendon undergraduate program. This is a 4+1 pathway, meaning you would spend the first 4 years completing your undergraduate degree at Glendon (in a discipline not related to business), then you would continue into the 1-year MMgt at the Schulich School of Business, for a total of 5 years.

You are interested in studying in a business-related field, you may be particularly interested in our programs in Economics, Business Economics or, if you have good knowledge of English and French, our Dual Degree (iBA/BBA) in International Studies and Business Administration, offered in partnership with emlyon Business School in France.

Students in these programs can also opt to specialize in Finance & Accounting in their 3rd and 4th years. I would like to pursue a program in marketing, what do you recommend?

Do you offer dentistry?
Unfortunately, none of Glendon’s programs can prepare students for entry into dentistry schools. There are simply too many requirements that we do not offer here at Glendon (chemistry among others).

I would encourage you to look at the programs offered by the Faculty of Science at York’s Keele campus, where the selection is wider. As a first step, you can look at the York program website for available programs. For more information, you can contact the Office of Admissions at study@yorku.ca or 416- 736-5000.
Do you offer a program to go to medicine?

To apply to a professional school offering a program in medicine in Ontario, a student must first have completed an undergraduate degree. In general, professional schools don’t require that students complete an undergraduate degree in a specific discipline. For example, a student could complete Glendon’s BSc in Biology or our BSc in Psychology and subsequently decide to apply to medical school. That said, it’s important to understand that meticulous planning is required from a student wanting to pursue this pathway. Most professional medical schools tend to have specific admission requirements. If you plan on coming to Glendon, it will be important that you openly discuss your desire to pursue a career in medicine with your academic advisor so that they can guide you.
Do you offer a Law program?

While we do not offer a program specifically in Law, we see many of our students go on to pursue law- related careers after studying in programs such as Philosophy, International Studies, Political Science, Sociology, Psychology and even History. Some students will also complete minors/majors in more than one subject area to give themselves a deeper exposure to the different fields directly and indirectly related to the practice of Law. If your goal is to eventually become a lawyer, it’s important to understand that, in Canada, you must first complete an undergraduate degree prior to applying to a professional school offering a law program (an example of such a school would be York’s Osgoode Hall Law School). Our Philosophy program in particular, has been shown to help students increase their LSAT scores when comes the time to apply to Law School. When they arrive at Glendon, many students will also choose to add our Certificate in Law & Social Thought to their degree program as it examines the study of law directly within the context of an education in the liberal arts. Remember that your eventual application to law school will require that you have good undergraduate grades, so it is important to choose a program in which you think you will do well.
Do you offer a program to become a Speech-Language Pathologist?

In Ontario, the pathway to Speech-Language Pathology (SLP) or Audiology is a graduate-level pathway. For educational pathways leading to an eventual career in SLP or Audiology, I would encourage you to take a look at this website, which has some good resources. In order to pursue a career in either of these areas, you will first need to complete a 4-year (Honours) degree, then spend another two to three years studying in a Master’s-level program specializing in SLP or Audiology. Many students explore this pathway by first completing our minor in Linguistics & Language Studies and then applying to a graduate-level program in an area of their choosing.
Do you offer a program to teach English as a second language (ESL)?

Teaching English as a second language (ESL) is something that interests you, you could complete the Certificate in the Discipline of Teaching English as an International Language (D-TEIL) alongside a Glendon undergraduate program, or as a standalone certificate if you already hold a university degree. The D-TEIL is a 24-credit certificate that is typically taken over the course of two years. You can read more about its requirements and the courses that are part of this Certificate in the Academic Calendar. The courses are taken in the order listed, culminating in the completion of a 3-week teaching practicum. If you are admitted to Glendon, you can speak to an academic advisor about adding the D-TEIL to your program of study (no need to apply at this point).
Should I go to college first?

For students looking to obtain a foundational base prior to starting in university, we generally recommend college-level General Arts & Science Diploma programs, particularly Liberal Arts University Transfer programs. These programs can be taken through any accredited college. To provide you with a few examples, York University has articulation agreements with Seneca College, Humber College and Centennial College for their Liberal Arts & University Transfer programs. The benefit of this type of

program is that it gives students a good foundation and can help aid their transition into a post- secondary environment. They also have the added benefit of being eligible for transfer credits that, depending on the program to which you apply, could potentially count toward the degree you are pursuing at York University.
Is it mandatory to do YU Prep?

York University offers workshops for incoming first-year university students, offering a mix of academic instruction, skill-building and personal development opportunities. Students can choose subjects that support their interests and individual learning goals. Some workshops subjects are;
grow your confidence and skills in academic reading, writing and note-taking;
review the fundamentals of math such as algebra, trigonometry, functions and derivatives;
refresh your knowledge of science concepts in biology, chemistry and physics; and
explore customized supports for international students and other specialized audiences.
These classes are not mandatory and do not give credits toward your degree. You can read more about the YU Prep module offerings on York’s website.
What is the difference between Linguistics & Language Studies and Translation?

Both programs focus on languages but examine them from very different angles. The Linguistics and Language Studies program focuses on the building blocks of languages, on how languages change over time, on language acquisition, etc. The Translation program focuses on the use of languages – perfecting your writing skills in your 1st language and improving your competence in your 2nd language through writing, research, translation theory and the practice of translation. Students in both programs have a general love for languages. You can find more information by clicking on this link: https://www.yorku.ca/glendon/programs/
I have the choice of going to Keele or Glendon, what is the difference between both?
There are many things that set Glendon’s apart from the program offered through the Keele campus:

Glendon is much smaller than Keele – with only about 2,000 students in total, this works out to an average of 26 students per class (and often less, especially when you get into the upper years of your degree). This means that you will be able to benefit from very close contact with your professors and peers, more research opportunities, etc.

Glendon students are given many unique opportunities to engage in various kinds of applied experiences during their studies at Glendon, through different opportunities available through various employers and community partners. As a starting point, I’d encourage you to take a look at Glendon’s Experiential Education website, which outlines some of the opportunities that are available to students.

Glendon students can graduate with a bilingual (English-French) degree – more information about this here. This has the potential of setting you apart from your peers after graduation and can open up bilingual (and often better paying!) job opportunities. We also offer the option for students who are interested to explore trilingual (English-French-Spanish) options.
Glendon also offers its students multiple opportunities for international exchanges – 3 times more than the national average, in fact! You can read more about this here.

Glendon also offers some unique programs not available to Keele students. For example, if you are interested in potentially pursuing a career as a French as a second language (FSL) teacher, our BEd program, which is reserved to Glendon graduates only, may be of particular interest to you.

And remember – as a Glendon student, you are still part of York University (the 4th largest university in Canada!), so you will also have access to all the services at the Keele campus (libraries, cafeterias, clubs, gym, services, etc.). This is a way to get the best of both worlds! You can take advantage of the free shuttle service; https://www.yorku.ca/transportation/glendon- keele-shuttle/between Keele and Glendon to go back and forth between both campuses. See the link for the shuttle schedule here: https://www.yorku.ca/transportation/glendon-keele- shuttle/
In conclusion, why Glendon?

With our small class sizes (our average class size is 26 students), you will be able to get to know your professors better and have access to opportunities that may not be as readily available at a larger institution.

You can read more about the Certificate in Spanish-English/English-Spanish Translation on our website. This certificate involves the completion of 30 undergraduate-level credits, including some mandatory credits and some credits in a writing-intensive course. You can read more about the certificate requirements in the Academic Calendar here.

If you intend to take the certificate as a standalone, you must successfully complete an entrance exam during the application process. You can reach out to the certificate coordinator at certificado@glendon.yorku.ca for more information and to set up a time to write the exam.

Teaching English as a second language (ESL) is something that might also interest you, you could consider completing the Certificate in the Discipline of Teaching English as an International Language (D- TEIL) alongside your undergraduate program (whether it be English Studies or a different undergraduate program). The D-TEIL is a 24-credit certificate that is typically taken over the course of two years. The courses are taken in the order listed, culminating in the completion of a 3-week teaching practicum.

The Certificate in Spanish for Business and Professional Communication is an 18-credit certificate that includes 12 core credits and 6 elective credits.
