I would like more information about the program in Education?

Glendon’s BEd (with FSL concentration) is a bilingual (English-French) program that addresses the provincial need to train well-qualified French as a Second Language (FSL) teachers. This program is specifically designed to prepare teachers who will be teaching in the Anglophone school boards offering the immersion, Extended and Core French programming in Ontario.
Future students need to apply to our Concurrent BEd, which simply means you will be simultaneously applying to your Glendon undergraduate program and Glendon’s FSL BEd.

There are two Concurrent BEd program options that are linked to Glendon. Please note that both of these Concurrent BEd programs are open only to students applying directly from high school. You can read more about these two options on our website:

OUAC program YGJ, which involves the completion of an undergraduate degree at Glendon (generally, this would be the BA in French Studies), followed by the BEd (with concentration on French as a Second Language) at Glendon;

OUAC program YYI, which involves the completion of an undergraduate degree at Glendon (a BA/BSc program, based on the subject area in which you eventually want to teach), followed by the BEd (in English) at the Keele campus.

Students applying to a Concurrent BEd program are required to submit a supplementary application, including a personal statement, experience profile and summary, two online letters of reference, a $50 processing fee and, in the case of an application to Glendon’s FSL BEd, a French placement test. You can

read a little more about the supplementary application here and here. If an applicant wishes to be considered for both options, they should submit an application to both programs in OUAC. However, they would only need to submit one supplementary application. If you have specific inquiries and questions about our program in Education (BEd), you can book a virtual appointment with Jennifer, the Glendon BEd Recruitment Specialist, or click here: https://calendly.com/jennifer_chweiri/admissions_advising_glendon?back=1&month=2023-08
I have a college degree and I am interested in doing the Bachelor of Education, I am eligible?

There are two entry points to Glendon’s BEd – through our concurrent model (for students applying directly out of high school), and through our consecutive model (for students with post-secondary history). Because you have already completed college-level studies, you unfortunately wouldn’t be eligible to apply through the Concurrent model BEd – however, you could consider an eventual application to our Consecutive BEd. It is very important to understand that Glendon’s BEd with FSL concentration is reserved only to Glendon graduates, so it will be very important that you complete an undergraduate degree at Glendon if this pathway interests you. You would be eligible to apply to Glendon’s Consecutive BEd in the final year of your Glendon undergraduate degree. If you have more question about the application, please send an email to liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.

Should you wish to apply to a Glendon undergraduate program, you can do so through the Ontario Universities Application Centre (OUAC), or directly on York’s website. The application deadlines can be seen on our website, based on applicant type. Please note; if you are interested in teaching Extended and Core French programming in Ontario. York also offers a BEd program at its Keele campus, which is taught in English.
I have taken some courses at another university; can I apply to Glendon's education program?

There are two entry points to Glendon’s BEd – through our concurrent model (for students applying directly out of high school), and through our consecutive model (for students with post-secondary history). Because you have already completed college-level studies or some University courses, you unfortunately wouldn’t be eligible to apply through the Concurrent model BEd – however, you could consider an eventual application to our Consecutive BEd. It is very important to understand that Glendon’s BEd with FSL concentration is reserved only to Glendon graduates, so it will be very important that you complete an undergraduate degree at Glendon if this pathway interests you. You would be eligible to apply to Glendon’s Consecutive BEd in the final year of your Glendon undergraduate degree. If you have more question about the application, please send an email to liaison@glendon.yorku.ca.

Should you wish to apply to a Glendon undergraduate program, you can do so through the Ontario Universities Application Centre (OUAC), or directly on York’s website. The application deadlines can be seen on our website, based on applicant type. Please note; if you are interested in teaching Extended and Core French programming in Ontario. York also offers a BEd program at its Keele campus, which is taught in English.
I already hold a UNIVERSITY DEGREE FROM ANOTHER INSTITUTION, can
I apply to Glendon’s Education program?

You are unfortunately not able to apply to Glendon’s BEd with a degree from another institution. If you wanted to eventually be eligible to apply to our BEd with FSL concentration (through our Consecutive model), you would need to be prepared to complete a second undergraduate degree at Glendon (which would most typically be in French Studies). You would be able to apply to our BEd consecutively in the final year of your Glendon undergraduate degree. If this is a pathway that interests you, please contact liaison@glendon.yorku.ca

Students who already hold a university degree and who do not want to complete a 2nd degree at Glendon can consider applying to the Consecutive BEd offered at York’s Keele campus. Contrary to Glendon’s BEd, you do not need to have completed your undergraduate degree at the same institution in order to apply. FSL is also an accepted teaching subject for eligible candidates wishing to pursue the Junior/Intermediate (grades 4 to 10) and Intermediate/Senior (grades 7 to 12) options. However, it’s important to note that Keele’s BEd is offered in English and, contrary to Glendon’s program, your teaching placements are not guaranteed to be in an FSL setting. If you have any questions about your eligibility to apply to the Consecutive BEd at Keele, I’d encourage you to reach out to the Faculty of Education at osp@edu.yorku.ca.
What is the difference between the Education program at GLENDON and KEELE?

What makes Glendon’s BEd program different from other BEd programs is that it offers specific focus on teaching French within a 2nd language learning context. The program is bilingual, and your teaching placements are guaranteed to be in a FSL context (i.e. within an Anglophone school offering the immersion, Extended or Core French programming). You can find some useful information about this here. Keele’s BEd program is entirely in English and, while FSL is an accepted teaching subject at both the Junior/Intermediate and Intermediate/Senior levels, your teaching placements are not guaranteed to be within a FSL context.
What is the average (GPA) REQUIREMENT FOR ADMISSION?
We typically look for a minimum overall average in the high 70s for admission to our undergraduate- level programs.
What is the alternate offer that I am seeing in OUAC?

The alternate offer you are seeing in OUAC is related to your YGJ application. When you applied to the Concurrent BEd in OUAC, you were in effect applying to two different programs – the BA in French Studies, and the Bachelor of Education (or BEd), which involves an additional 2 years of study after the completion of your undergraduate degree (i.e. your BA). It is completely normal for your undergraduate offer to appear as an alternate offer in OUAC when it is coupled with an application to a Concurrent BEd program. This is because admission to each program is treated separately, meaning you are not automatically admitted to the Concurrent BEd upon admission to your undergraduate program.
When it comes to admission decisions for the Concurrent BEd, there are a few things to consider:

You will need to have been granted an offer of admission to your undergraduate program by mid-April. You’ve already met this very important first milestone, which is great! You can check this one off your list!
In order for your application to continue to be considered for admission to the Concurrent BEd, you will need to submit your supplementary application, which includes:
an experience profile
an experience summary
a personal statement
two online letters of reference
a $50 processing fee
a French placement test
When will I receive more information about the supplementary application?

Concurrent BEd applicants will not have access to their supplementary application until after the application deadline has passed. In late January/early February, all applicants will receive more information from the Faculty of Education about their Supplementary Information Forms (which will be submitted through MyFile), as well as their $50 processing fee. If you have applied to Glendon’s Concurrent BEd, you can expect to receive the access information for your French placement from liaison@glendon.yorku.ca in early February. In the meantime, here are some good tips for putting together a strong supplementary application.
What do I have to submit for my supplementary application to be considered for the Bachelor of education (BEd)?

You can expect to receive more information about the additional documents to be submitted alongside your BEd application simultaneously towards the end of January/early February. Stay tuned for an email from the Faculty of Education!

Students applying to Glendon’s Concurrent BEd (with French as a Second Language focus) are required to submit a supplementary application, including a personal statement, experience profile and summary, two online letters of reference, French placement test and a $50 processing fee. You can read a little more about the supplementary application here and here.
What are the reference letters that I need to submit for my supplementary application?

Candidates for the Concurrent B.Ed. program must submit two online references as part of their supplementary application. When you submit the name of a person as a reference, they will automatically receive an email invitation. They will be asked to answer a few questions about you and evaluate you based on certain criteria. They also have the option to write a letter to support their reference. Generally, we recommend that you ask people who are willing to write a letter for you.

Ideally, the individuals you select should be able to speak about your overall potential as a future teaching candidate, your ability to work with children/teenagers (if they are able to do so), and, in the context of your passion for French, languages, or second language acquisition.
CAN I BE EXEMPTED FROM WRITING THE FRENCH PLACEMENT TEST IF I AM WRITING ANOTHER FRENCH PROFICIENCY TEST (YGJ APPLICANTS)?

The French placement test is an internal metric used by our BEd selection committee to ascertain your current level of French. Because it is a Glendon-specific test, it cannot be replaced with another language proficiency test.
What is the content of the French placement test for YGJ candidates?

Our B.Ed. candidates with a concentration in FSL must have strong oral and written French skills. To assess their French proficiency, all B.Ed. candidates at Glendon will take our French language proficiency evaluation as part of the application process. This test includes multiple-choice and short-answer questions. The test aims to measure your overall proficiency in French.
Can I be part time when doing the Bed program?

The BEd program is mainly on a full-time basis and in-person. It isn’t possible yet to complete Glendon’s FSL BEd on a part-time basis or online. The BEd program is offered on a full-time basis during daytime hours (no courses are offered on evenings/weekends or online). Also, 2 days per week are allocated to teaching placements in the community/schools, which are also only during the day. In other words, your daytime availability and your physical presence in Toronto would be required in order to partake in this program.
I have not received the information about the supplementary application for the dual degree?

If you have not received the information about how to submit the supplementary application for the dual degree, send an email to liaison@glendon.yorku.ca, please write your student number in your email for reference.
